sub_topic: Interpolation and extrapolation of data using Lagrange polynomials
message_1: Suppose you have a set of data points (2, 5), (5, 12), and (7, 9). Using Lagrange interpolation, find the polynomial P(x) that passes through these points and use it to estimate the y-coordinate of the point that lies halfway between the second and third data points.
message_2:
To find the polynomial P(x) using Lagrange interpolation, we can use the formula:

P(x) = L_0(x) * y_0 + L_1(x) * y_1 + L_2(x) * y_2

where L_i(x) are the Lagrange basis polynomials and y_i are the y-coordinates of the given data points.

The Lagrange basis polynomials are defined as:

L_0(x) = (x - x_1)(x - x_2) / ((x_0 - x_1)(x_0 - x_2))
L_1(x) = (x - x_0)(x - x_2) / ((x_1 - x_0)(x_1 - x_2))
L_2(x) = (x - x_0)(x - x_1) / ((x_2 - x_0)(x_2 - x_1))

Using the given data points (2, 5), (5, 12), and (7, 9), we can calculate the Lagrange basis polynomials:

L_0(x) = (x - 5)(x - 7) / ((2 - 5)(2 - 7)) = (x - 5)(x - 7) / 15
L_1(x) = (x - 2)(x - 7) / ((5 - 2)(5 - 7)) = (x - 2)(x - 7) / -6
L_2(x) = (x - 2)(x - 5) / ((7 - 2)(7 - 5)) = (x - 2)(x - 5) / 10

Now, we can find the polynomial P(x):

P(x) = L_0(x) * 5 + L_1(x) * 12 + L_2(x) * 9
P(x) = (5/15)(x - 5)(x - 7) - (12/6)(x - 2)(x - 7) + (9/10)(x - 2)(x - 5)

To estimate the y-coordinate of the point halfway between the second and third data points, we need to find the x-coordinate halfway between 5 and 7:

x_half = (5 + 7) / 2 = 6

Now, we can plug this x-coordinate into our polynomial P(x):

P(6) = (5/15)(6 - 5)(6 - 7) - (12/6)(6 - 2)(6 - 7) + (9/10)(6 - 2)(6 - 5)
P(6) = (1/3)(1)(-1) - 2(4)(-1) + (9/10)(4)(1)
P(6) = -1/3 + 8 + 36/10
P(6) = 79/10

So, the estimated y-coordinate of the point halfway between the second and third data points is 79/10 or 7.9.
